issues.title: Why rotating keys often benefits from a TS might need a good ref on key rotation
issues.author: henkbirkholz
issues.body:
>In cases where the issuer or holder might rotate verification keys frequently, or where the issuer or holder might not be well known to a verifier, a receipt from a notary can provide assurance to the verifier.

@OR13 highlighted that key rotation might not be the perfect term, but the NIST glossary definition fits:

`https://csrc.nist.gov/glossary/term/key_rotation`

Then adding a few sentences about bcp on key management from SP.800p2 and cite the source could do the trick:

`
https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/SpecialPublications/NIST.SP.800-57pt2r1.pdf`

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body:
@cabo pointed out cryptoperiods in NIST SP 800.

Cryptoperiods:
```
If a key is retained indefinitely for operational use (e.g., for encryption, decryption, or signing), the probability that
the key will become known through cryptanalysis, technical probing, malware, carelessness, or other methods
increases over time. Depending on the criticality, volume, or perishability of the information being protected,
longer or shorter operational lifetimes may be established for cryptographic keys. Some private-sector
organizations neither change key variables and/or certificates nor make provision for users to change the keys
and/or certificates. This is not recommended if the information has any privacy or security value. Ideally, an
organization controls cryptoperiod determinations for the keys that protect its information.
```

comments.author: OR13
comments.body:
We should use the word "rotation" so that people searching for it find "cryptoperiods"... and then say.

The term "key rotation" typically implies establishing reasonable cryptoperiods, and not reusing any keys which have expired.

issues.title: Principle or principal?
issues.author: aj-stein-nist
issues.body:
Hi, I was casually reviewing this draft because you had mentioned the diagrams elsewhere, and the topic still interests me so I read it. One thing that caught my eye is this draft defines an identifier as a principle and not principal. The latter makes more sense to me [and a quick search confirms this is what OAuth uses](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-oauth-assertions-05), and I assume others.

Is this a typo? I will be doing a quick PR shortly, replacing all use of principle with principal, which seems to be the intent and is a very easy fix (I hope).

If I misunderstood feel free to tell me so and close it.

issues.title: Consider Reputation as an analog to Transparency
issues.author: openprivacy
issues.body:
This is fascinating! Thank you @aj-stein-nist for bringing this to my attention. More discussion than issue:

While there can be well-known public verification entities, a verifier can be very specific, perhaps personal, consisting of a collection of verifier services both public and private.  This enables a local, target-specific trust metric that yields a reputational scoring. Zero-knowledge mechanisms can provide blinded authentication and reputation calculation.

As such, Transparency Tokens could provide a basis for an agoric, reputation-based marketplace.

pulls.title: Principle->principal where relevant
pulls.author: aj-stein-nist
pulls.body:
Correct principle to principle as needed, closing #5.

In some cases, this draft is discussing principles for using identities.

In other cases, this draft is using the defined term in this draft for a Principal and its relationship to an Identifier.

These changes correct the latter where writing it as the former. This likely seems to be incorrect.

comments.author: aj-stein-nist
comments.body: It took me a few reads to catch myself replacing them all, but the [Credential Principles](https://or13.github.io/draft-steele-spice-transparency-tokens/draft-steele-transparency-tokens.html#section-4) Section is using the word as spelled with its common non-technical definition, so I left it as-is.
